channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Who is Larry Ellison, the billionaire Trump friend who's part of the TikTok takeover?
item.description: Larry Ellison has a lower profile than other tech billionaires, but his influence over media is about to be immense. His family's empire could soon own CBS, Paramount, CNN and TikTok.
item.content:encoded: Larry Ellison has a lower profile than other tech billionaires, but his influence over media is about to be immense. His family's empire could soon own CBS, Paramount, CNN and TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: Psychiatrists call for RFK Jr. to be replaced as health secretary
item.description: Two groups are calling for new leadership at HHS after Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s actions on substance abuse treatment and mental health medications, among other issues.
item.content:encoded:
Two groups are calling for new leadership at HHS after Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s actions on substance abuse treatment and mental health medications, among other issues.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Rhitu Chatterjee

item.title: Who is Bari Weiss? CBS News' new editor-in-chief is a vocal critic of legacy media
item.description: Provocative columnist Bari Weiss publicly quit the New York Times in 2020, then cofounded The Free Press as an alternative to legacy media. Here's what to know as she takes the helm of CBS News.
item.content:encoded:
Provocative columnist Bari Weiss publicly quit the New York Times in 2020, then cofounded The Free Press as an alternative to legacy media. Here's what to know as she takes the helm of CBS News.

(Image credit: Leigh Vogel)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: ICC finds former Sudan militia leader guilty of war crimes in Darfur
item.description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.
item.content:encoded:
The International Criminal Court in The Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.

(Image credit: Koen Van Weel)
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: Bread and Puppet Theater is still working to 'make the revolution irresistible'
item.description: The decades-old radical troupe Bread and Puppet, famed for its protest art including giant puppets, is touring again — mixing circus, politics and bread in a sharply polarized moment.
item.content:encoded: The decades-old radical troupe Bread and Puppet, famed for its protest art including giant puppets, is touring again — mixing circus, politics and bread in a sharply polarized moment.
item.dc:creator: Neda Ulaby

item.title: The federal government is shut down. Here's what that means across the country
item.description: The federal government is currently shut down. NPR's network is following the ways the government shutdown is affecting services across the country.
item.content:encoded:
The federal government is currently shut down. NPR's network is following the ways the government shutdown is affecting services across the country.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: The NPR Network

item.title: The CDC says people must consult a health professional before COVID shot
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention accepted a controversial recommendation from outside vaccine advisers to tighten guidelines for the COVID vaccine.
item.content:encoded:
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention accepted a controversial recommendation from outside vaccine advisers to tighten guidelines for the COVID vaccine.

(Image credit: FREDERIC J. BROWN)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Federal judge declines to immediately block National Guard deployment in Illinois
item.description: Illinois asked a judge to block the Trump administration from federalizing the Illinois National Guard and from sending Guard members from other states, but the judge declined to do so, for now.
item.content:encoded:
Illinois asked a judge to block the Trump administration from federalizing the Illinois National Guard and from sending Guard members from other states, but the judge declined to do so, for now.

(Image credit: Mathieu Lewis-Rolland/Getty Images; Vincent Alban/Getty Images; Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: A major census test begins recruiting workers as some warn about delays
item.description: The Census Bureau is looking for temporary workers to carry out next year's major field test of the 2030 census in six states, as the national head count's advocates raise concerns about preparations.
item.content:encoded:
The Census Bureau is looking for temporary workers to carry out next year's major field test of the 2030 census in six states, as the national head count's advocates raise concerns about preparations.

(Image credit: John Raoux)
item.dc:creator: Hansi Lo Wang

item.title: How one country has become a top destination for hair transplants
item.description: With more than 1 million people going to Turkey for the procedure every year, hair transplants are transforming men's scalps — and vanity. But not every story ends with a perfect hairline.
item.content:encoded:
With more than 1 million people going to Turkey for the procedure every year, hair transplants are transforming men's scalps — and vanity. But not every story ends with a perfect hairline.

(Image credit: Ozan Kose)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Rosman
